Section.MarginalNote: Weapons, explosive substances and threat items
Section.Text: A licensee must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weapons are not taken into a protected area or inner area unless they are under the control of a peace officer, nuclear security officer or a member of an on-site nuclear response force or off-site response force who requires access to the area for the purpose of carrying out their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: explosive substances are not taken into a protected area or inner area unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are under the control of a peace officer, nuclear security officer or a member of an on-site nuclear response force or off-site response force who requires access to the area for the purpose of carrying out their duties; or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are necessary for an operational requirement and are under the control of a person who is authorized by the licensee and escorted at all times by a nuclear security officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: threat items are not taken into a protected area or inner area unless they are necessary for an operational requirement.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must ensure that Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material is not removed from a protected area or inner area except in accordance with a licence.
A licensee must ensure that Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material is not removed from a vital area without its authorization.

Section.Text: A person must not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: take any weapons into a protected area or inner area unless they are under the control of a peace officer, nuclear security officer or a member of an on-site nuclear response force or an off-site response force who requires access to the area for the purpose of carrying out their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take any explosive substance into a protected area or an inner area unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a peace officer, nuclear security officer or a member of an on-site nuclear response force or off-site response force who requires access to the area for the purpose of carrying out their duties, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are authorized to do so by the licensee and escorted at all times by a nuclear security officer and the explosive substance is necessary for an operational requirement;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: take threat items into a protected area or inner area unless they are necessary for an operational requirement; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: remove any Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material from a protected area, vital area or inner area without the authorization of the licensee.

Section.Text: Before a person who has been granted an authorization under section 49 enters a protected area, the licensee must verify their identity by two separate personnel identity verification systems, one of which must use biometric information.
The licensee must verify and record the identity of every person who enters a vital area.
A licensee must not permit a land vehicle to enter a protected area, vital area or inner area unless there is an operational requirement for it to be in that area.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must ensure that land vehicles only enter into or exit from a protected area through a vehicle portal or, if necessary for an operational requirement, through an opening with two moveable barriers.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Both barriers not to be open
Subsection.Text: Both moveable barriers of a vehicle portal or opening must not be open at the same time except in the event of an emergency or if it is necessary to do so for an operational requirement.
When both moveable barriers of a vehicle portal or opening are open at the same time, the vehicle portal or opening, as the case may be, must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: attended by at least one nuclear security officer who is equipped with a land vehicle; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: protected by other nuclear security measures that prevent unauthorized access to the protected area.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must not permit a gate, door, window or other means of entry or exit in the structure that encloses an inner area to be unlocked, opened or kept open except for the period of time necessary to allow for the passage of persons or items into or out of the area or for the completion of an operational requirement.

While the means of entry or exit is unlocked, opened or kept open, the licensee must ensure that it is under the direct visual surveillance of a nuclear security officer who is dedicated exclusively to that task.

A licensee must not permit a gate, door, window or other means of entry or exit in the structure that encloses an inner area to be unlocked from the outside unless it is unlocked by two persons who are authorized to enter the inner area, at least one of whom is a nuclear security officer.

Section.Text: A person who is authorized under subsection 52(1) to enter and remain in an inner area must not enter the area unless they are accompanied by another person who is authorized to do so under that subsection and they remain in visual contact with that other person.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must post, in close proximity to the location at which the search of persons is conducted, signage that is visible to any person who is about to enter a high-security site that states, in English and French, that all persons entering and exiting the site and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on entering the site, subject to search by a nuclear security officer — using any necessary screening and detection devices — for weapons, explosive substances, threat items and, in the case of a land vehicle, unauthorized persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on exiting the site, subject to search by a nuclear security officer for Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material and Category III nuclear material using devices capable of detecting that material.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Signage for protected area and inner area
Subsection.Text: A licensee must post, in close proximity to the location at which the search of persons is conducted, signage that is visible to any person who is about to enter a protected area or inner area that states, in English and French, that all persons entering and exiting the area and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on entering the area, subject to search by a nuclear security officer — using any necessary screening and detection devices — for weapons, explosive substances, threat items and, in the case of a land vehicle, unauthorized persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on exiting the area, subject to search by a nuclear security officer for Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material and Category III nuclear material using devices capable of detecting that material.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a licensee must not permit any person to enter a protected area or inner area unless the person and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, are searched by a nuclear security officer — using any necessary detection and screening devices — for weapons, explosive substances, threat items and, in the case of a land vehicle, unauthorized persons.

Subject to subsection (3), a licensee must ensure that all persons exiting a protected area or inner area and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, are searched by a nuclear safety officer for Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material and Category III nuclear material using devices capable of detecting that material.
The following persons are not subject to a search under subsection (1) or (2):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a nuclear security officer whose identity has been verified in accordance with section 74 and who requires access to or egress from the protected area or inner area for the purposes of carrying out their duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who, if they were granted an authorization to enter the area with an escort, is or was escorted in accordance with that authorization and who establishes to a nuclear security officer — by presentation of identification or other evidence — that they are a member of the off-site response force, a peace officer or a member of an emergency service who requires access to or egress from the protected area or inner area for the purpose of carrying out their duties.

Subsection.Text: If the licensee has reasonable grounds to suspect that a person who is in a protected area or inner area has any of the following items in their possession, the licensee must not permit the person to remain in that area unless the person and everything in their possession, including a land vehicle, is searched for those items:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weapons or explosive substances that are not under the control of a nuclear security officer or a member of an on-site nuclear response force or off-site response force;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: threat items that are not necessary for an operational requirement; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material that is being removed from the area without the authorization of the licensee.

Subsection.Text: A search of a person that is conducted under this section must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a non-intrusive search carried out by means of a hand-held scanner, a walk-through scanner equipped with a metal detector or any similar device; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a frisk search carried out by a person of the same sex as the person being searched and extending from head to foot, down the front and rear of the body, around the legs and inside clothing folds, pockets and footwear, if a nuclear security officer determines that it is necessary in order to maintain security.

Subsection.Text: If the high-security site is equipped with a vehicle portal, a search of a land vehicle that is conducted under this section must take place in the vehicle portal.

Section.Text: A person who refuses to submit to a search to which they are subject under section 81 must not enter a protected area or inner area.
In this Part, licensee means a person who, in relation to a nuclear facility referred to in paragraph 3(c) of these Regulations, is licensed under the Act to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carry out an activity described in any of paragraphs 26(a), (e) or (f) of the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: produce, refine, convert, enrich, process, reprocess, manage, store or dispose of a nuclear substance.

Section.Text: This Part applies in respect of the nuclear facilities referred to in paragraph 3(c).

Subsection.Text: A licensee may grant a facility-access security clearance to a person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it determines, after verifying the information and documents referred to in subsection (2), that the person does not pose an unreasonable risk to the health or safety of persons or the security of the nuclear facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it verifies that the person holds

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a valid facility-access security clearance, a high-security site access clearance or an enhanced security clearance granted by another licensee, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a valid reliability status or a secret or top secret clearance granted under the Directive on Security Screening.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of paragraph (1)(a), the licensee must verify the following information and documents in respect of the person who is seeking the facility-access security clearance:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two pieces of valid government-issued identification, one of which must be photo identification;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a record that sets out the results of any criminal record check, such as a check that is fingerprint-based; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: their personal history for the last five years, composed of their educational history, professional qualifications, employment history and character references, but if their history cannot be established for that period, information relating to their trustworthiness, including, if available, the results of a criminal record check from each country in which they have resided for one or more years in the last five years.

Subsection.Text: A facility-access security clearance may be granted for a term not exceeding 10 years and must be subject to any terms and conditions that are necessary to minimize the risk to the security of the nuclear facility.

A licensee that grants a facility-access security clearance under paragraph (1)(b) must keep a record indicating how it verified that the person holds a status or clearance, as the case may be, referred to in that paragraph.
A licensee must keep an up-to-date list of the persons to whom a facility-access security clearance has been granted.
The licensee must, on request, provide a copy of the list to the Commission or an inspector.
A licensee must revoke a person’s facility-access security clearance if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licensee concludes, based on an investigation, that the person poses or could pose an unreasonable risk to the health or safety of persons or the security of the nuclear facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is no longer employed by or otherwise under contract to the licensee;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s duties have been completed, suspended or otherwise terminated;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person no longer requires the clearance to carry out their duties; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the person provided false or misleading information to obtain the clearance.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must notify the Commission in writing of any revocation made under paragraph (1)(a) or (e) within five business days after the day on which the revocation is made.

Section.MarginalNote: Entering or remaining in nuclear facility

Subsection.Text: A person must not enter or remain in a nuclear facility at which a licensee carries out licensed activities unless they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a facility-access security clearance that is granted in respect of that facility by the licensee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are escorted at all times by a person who has such a clearance; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are an inspector who is designated to carry out inspections at nuclear facilities or a person who is chosen by the inspector to accompany them under section 33 of the Act.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(b), a member of the off-site response force, a peace officer or a member of an emergency service is not required to be escorted if there is an emergency at the facility and they require access to it for the purpose of carrying out their duties.
A licensee must ensure that every person who enters or remains in a nuclear facility at which it carries on licensed activities is permitted to do so under subsection 88(1).

The licensee must establish and implement a process that controls access to the nuclear facility and that ensures that the identity of each person who enters the facility, other than one referred to in paragraph 88(1)(c), is verified by,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who has a facility-access security clearance for that facility, presentation of proof of their clearance and use of a device that is capable of verifying their identity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any other person who is 18 years of age or over, presentation of two pieces of valid government-issued identification, one of which must be photo identification; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who is under the age of 18, presentation of documentary proof of their name and address.

Section.MarginalNote: Weapons, explosive substances and threat items
Section.Text: A licensee must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weapons are not taken into a nuclear facility unless they are under the control of a peace officer or member of the off-site response force who requires access to the nuclear facility for the purpose of carrying out their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: explosive substances are not taken into a nuclear facility unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are under the control of a peace officer or member of the off-site response force who requires access to the nuclear facility for the purpose of carrying out their duties; or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are necessary for an operational requirement and they are under the control of a person who is authorized by the licensee and kept under the direct visual surveillance of a person authorized by the licensee; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: threat items are not taken into a nuclear facility unless they are necessary for an operational requirement.

Section.Text: A person must not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: take any weapon into a nuclear facility unless they are a peace officer or a member of the off-site response force who requires access to the nuclear facility for the purpose of carrying out their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take any explosive substance into a nuclear facility unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a peace officer or a member of the off-site response force who requires access to the nuclear facility for the purpose of carrying out their duties, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are authorized to do so by the licensee and placed under the direct visual surveillance of a person authorized by the licensee and the explosive substance is necessary for an operational requirement;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: take any threat item into a nuclear facility unless it is necessary for an operational requirement; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: remove any nuclear substance from a nuclear facility without the authorization of the licensee.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must not permit a land vehicle to enter a nuclear facility at which the licensee carries on a licensed activity unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the land vehicle is searched for explosive substances, weapons, threat items and unauthorized persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an operational requirement for the vehicle to be there or it is used by a member of the off-site response force, a peace officer or a member of an emergency service for the purpose of carrying out their duties.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(a), a vehicle that is used by a security guard, a member of the off-site response force, a peace officer or a member of an emergency service is not required to be searched if there is an emergency at the nuclear facility and the use of the vehicle is necessary to carry out their duties.

Section.Text: A licensee must post, in close proximity to the location at which the search and screening of persons is conducted, signage that is visible to any person who is about to enter the nuclear facility that states, in English and French, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: persons entering and exiting the facility may be subject to search or screening for explosive substances, weapons, threat items or nuclear substances; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licensee must not allow any person who has been selected for search or screening to enter the facility unless that person and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, is searched or screened.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must implement processes that, using a risk-based approach, provide for the manner of selecting the persons who are to be searched or screened, respectively,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on entering a nuclear facility, for explosive substances, weapons and threat items; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on exiting a nuclear facility, for nuclear substances.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must not permit any person who is selected for search or screening to enter the nuclear facility unless the person and everything in their possession, including any land vehicle, is searched or screened.

Section.Text: A search or screening referred to in section 94 must be carried out by a person who is authorized to do so by the licensee and must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a non-intrusive search or screening that is carried out by means of a hand-held scanner, a walk-through scanner equipped with a metal detector or any similar device; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a frisk search carried out by a person of the same sex as the person being searched and extending from head to foot, down the front and rear of the body, around the legs and inside clothing folds, pockets and footwear, if a security guard or other person authorized by the licensee determines that it is necessary in order to maintain security.

Subsection.Text: A licensee must, in cooperation with the off-site response force, at least once every five years, conduct a security exercise that tests

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ability of selected elements of the contingency plan and selected nuclear security measures to ensure that an effective intervention can be made against, taking into account the threats identified in the threat and risk assessment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the readiness of the off-site response force and any security guards to respond to those threats.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must notify the Commission in writing of its intent to conduct a security exercise at least four months before the day on which the exercise is to be held.
The licensee must, for each security exercise that it conducts, keep a record that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an outline of the exercise scenario;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of the elements of the contingency plan and the nuclear security measures that were tested and the readiness of the off-site response force and, if any, the security guards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any corrective actions that, taking the evaluation into account, are necessary.

Subsection.Text: If a corrective action referred to in paragraph (3)(c) is to be implemented using a phased approach, the licensee must create a corrective action plan that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for the corrective action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rationale for the phased approach; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a timetable that sets out when each phase of the plan will be completed.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must implement the corrective actions and, if they are to be implemented using a phased approach, each phase must be completed in accordance with the timetable set out in the corrective action plan.

The licensee must, within 90 days after the day on which the security exercise is completed, provide to the Commission a copy of the record referred to in subsection (3) and, if any, a copy of the corrective action plan referred to in subsection (4).

Section.Text: In this Part, licensee means a person who is licensed to transport Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material.
This Part applies in respect of the transport of Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material.

Subsection.Text: A person may, without a licence to carry on that activity, transport Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material within an area in which the material is required by sections 19 to 21 to be produced, processed, used or stored.

For greater certainty, the exemption established under subsection (1) relates only to the activity specified in that subsection and does affect the licence requirement imposed by section 26 of the Act in relation to other activities.

Section.Text: An application for a licence to transport Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material or Category III nuclear material must contain, in addition to the information required under section 7 of the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations, 2015, a transport security plan that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, quantity, radiation level in Gy/h, chemical and physical characteristics and isotopic composition of the nuclear material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a threat and risk assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the conveyance and, if any, the escort arrangements;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed security measures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of how the applicant will evaluate and improve the security measures, including the proposed scheduling of security exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the planned route and at least one alternate route;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the tracking and communication arrangements made among the applicant, the operator of the land vehicle transporting the nuclear material, the recipient of the material and any off-site response force throughout the transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the arrangements made between the applicant and any off-site response force throughout the transport.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must conduct a security exercise in respect of the transport of Category I nuclear material, Category II nuclear material and Category III nuclear material at least once every five years.
The licensee must, for each security exercise that it conducts, keep a record that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an outline of the exercise scenario;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of the security measures that were tested; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any corrective actions that, taking the evaluation into account, are necessary.

Subsection.Text: If a corrective action referred to in paragraph (2)(c) is to be implemented using a phased approach, the licensee must create a corrective action plan that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for the corrective action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rationale for the phased approach; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a timetable that sets out when each phase of the plan will be completed.

Subsection.Text: The licensee must implement the corrective actions and, if they are to be implemented using a phased approach, each phase must be completed in accordance with the timetable set out in the corrective action plan.

The licensee must, within 90 days after the day on which the security exercise is completed, provide to the Commission a copy of the record referred to in subsection (2) and, if any, a copy of the corrective action plan referred to in subsection (3).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, former Regulations means the Nuclear Security Regulations as they read immediately before the day on which these Regulations come into force.
Unless the context otherwise requires, words and expressions used in this section have the same meaning as in section 1.

The former Regulations and Part 9 of the schedule to Administrative Monetary Penalties Regulations (Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission), as they read immediately before the day on which these Regulations come into force, continue to apply for two years after that day to a nuclear facility for which, on the day on which these Regulations come into force, a licence issued under the Act is in force.

If a person has been granted a clearance or issued an authorization under the former Regulations, that clearance or authorization remains valid until the expiry of the term for which it was granted or issued, and during that term the person may continue to access any area or information and carry out any duties and responsibilities that the clearance or authorization permitted them to access or carry out under the former Regulations.

If a person has been granted a site access security clearance under the former Regulations that is valid on the day on which these Regulations come into force and that, to maintain the person’s access to the nuclear facility, must be replaced by a facility-access security clearance granted under section 85, the licensee that granted the clearance may, before the term of the clearance expires, extend the term of the clearance to any term not exceeding 10 years.
